the qustion: Initiating an injectable GLP-1 receptor agonist is often preferred before starting insulin in most adults with type 2 diabetes who are not at target.
explanation: Preferred prior to insulin in many patients because of weight loss and low hypoglycemia risk. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Immediate insulin initiation is reasonable if the patient has catabolic symptoms (weight loss, polyuria/polydipsia), very high A1C, very high glucose, or ketonuria.
explanation: Insulin is indicated promptly in symptomatic or markedly uncontrolled hyperglycemia. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Therapy should be re-evaluated regularly, and intensification should not be delayed if goals are missed.
explanation: Treat-to-target approach; avoid clinical inertia. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Basal insulin targets fasting hyperglycemia and is usually the first insulin introduced in type 2 diabetes.
explanation: Basal-first strategy is standard to address fasting glucose. (Slide p. 6)

the qustion: If A1C remains above goal despite adequately titrated basal insulin, adding prandial insulin to the largest meal is an accepted next step.
explanation: Basal-plus strategy: add mealtime insulin to largest/most problematic meal. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: When ‘overbasalization’ is suspected (high basal dose with fasting at target but A1C above goal), simply pushing basal insulin higher is preferred over addressing postprandial glucose.
explanation: Address postprandial hyperglycemia (add GLP-1 RA or prandial insulin) instead of escalating basal indefinitely. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: Premixed insulin offers fewer injections but less flexibility and a greater need for consistent meal timing.
explanation: Premix trades convenience for flexibility and requires regular meals. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: GLP-1 receptor agonists commonly cause early gastrointestinal effects (e.g., nausea) that can be minimized by slow dose escalation and meal counseling.
explanation: Start low, go slow; dietary tips reduce GI symptoms. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Compared with prandial insulin add-on, combining a GLP-1 receptor agonist with basal insulin can lower hypoglycemia risk and body weight.
explanation: Basal + GLP-1 RA is an effective alternative to basal–bolus with weight and hypo benefits. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Tirzepatide (GIP/GLP-1 dual incretin) is a non-insulin injectable that can significantly lower A1C with weight loss benefits.
explanation: Dual incretin therapy is highlighted for potent glycemic and weight effects. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Insulin injection technique and site rotation are unimportant once the correct dose is found.
explanation: Technique and rotation prevent lipohypertrophy and variable absorption. (Slide p. 16)

the qustion: Basal insulin titration is typically guided by fasting glucose monitoring patterns rather than single values.
explanation: Use patterns over days to titrate safely. (Slide p. 6)

the qustion: A history of severe gastroparesis may influence the choice of GLP-1 receptor agonist therapy.
explanation: GLP-1 RAs can exacerbate gastric emptying delay; assess symptoms. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: GLP-1 receptor agonists have a high intrinsic risk of hypoglycemia when used without insulin or sulfonylureas.
explanation: Low intrinsic hypoglycemia risk unless combined with insulin/SU. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Some GLP-1 receptor agonists have demonstrated cardiovascular benefit in high-risk patients with type 2 diabetes.
explanation: Cardiovascular outcome data support certain GLP-1 RAs. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Weight neutrality or weight loss is typical for GLP-1 receptor agonists, in contrast to the weight gain often seen with insulin intensification.
explanation: Class effect includes weight reduction; insulin can increase weight. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Basal–bolus (MDI) regimens allow the greatest flexibility in meal timing and carbohydrate intake but require more injections and education.
explanation: MDI is flexible but resource-intensive. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Premixed insulin regimens are best suited for patients with highly variable meal schedules and unpredictable eating patterns.
explanation: Premix works better with consistent meal patterns. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: When adding a GLP-1 receptor agonist to basal insulin, it may be reasonable to reduce the basal dose modestly to avoid hypoglycemia if fasting values are already near goal.
explanation: Combination can lower glucose; consider cautious basal adjustment. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Insulin should be stored appropriately; extreme temperatures can impair potency and glycemic control.
explanation: Storage matters to maintain insulin effectiveness. (Slide p. 17)

the qustion: For many adults with T2D not at target on oral therapy, starting with premixed insulin is universally preferred over basal insulin or GLP-1 RA.
explanation: Basal or GLP-1 RA is usually preferred first; premix is selective. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: A GLP-1 receptor agonist can be considered in patients with obesity and suboptimal control because of its weight benefit and low hypoglycemia risk.
explanation: Weight and hypo profile favor GLP-1 RA in appropriate patients. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Adding small prandial insulin doses to the largest meal (‘basal-plus’) is one step toward full basal–bolus if A1C remains above goal.
explanation: Structured stepwise intensification. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: If fasting glucose is consistently controlled but A1C remains elevated, postprandial hyperglycemia is unlikely to be a contributor.
explanation: Elevated A1C with good fasting often reflects high postprandials. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: Sick-day rules are irrelevant for patients on insulin because doses are stable during illness.
explanation: Illness can raise glucose/ketones; education is essential. (Slide p. 18)

the qustion: Educating patients on hypoglycemia symptoms and management is a key part of initiating insulin therapy.
explanation: Safety education accompanies insulin starts. (Slide p. 15)

the qustion: Pen devices can improve accuracy and convenience of insulin administration for many patients compared with vials/syringes.
explanation: Device selection influences adherence and technique. (Slide p. 16)

the qustion: Long-acting basal analog insulin typically has a lower nocturnal hypoglycemia risk than NPH for many patients.
explanation: Profile and variability differ vs NPH; analogs often reduce nocturnal hypo. (Slide p. 6)

the qustion: Non-insulin injectables include GLP-1 receptor agonists and dual incretin therapies; SGLT2 inhibitors are oral agents, not injectables.
explanation: Clarifies classes and routes of administration. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: Some injectable therapies may confer renal and cardiovascular risk reduction in appropriate high-risk patients with type 2 diabetes.
explanation: Benefits highlighted for select agents/classes. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: In a newly diagnosed patient with T2D and catabolic symptoms and very high glucose, the best next step is typically:
a: Start GLP-1 RA and wait 6 months
explanation: Immediate insulin when symptomatic/markedly uncontrolled. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which strategy best targets fasting hyperglycemia first in T2D?
b: Basal insulin titrated to fasting targets
explanation: Basal insulin addresses fasting glucose. (Slide p. 6)

the qustion: A patient on adequately titrated basal insulin still has A1C above target with near-goal fasting glucose. Next best option?
b: Add mealtime insulin to the largest meal (basal-plus)
c: Stop insulin and add TZD instead
d: No change; repeat A1C in a year
explanation: Address postprandial excursions; basal-plus or GLP-1 RA. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which is an advantage of starting a GLP-1 RA before insulin in many patients?
a: Lower hypoglycemia risk and weight loss
explanation: Favorable weight and hypoglycemia profile. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: A patient on basal insulin is gaining weight and reports frequent late-evening hypos despite fasting glucose near target. Which change best fits ‘overbasalization’?
a: Reduce basal and add GLP-1 RA or small prandial dose
d: Switch to premix with no meal planning
explanation: Shift focus to postprandial coverage/GLP-1 RA. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: Which pairing is CORRECT about regimen characteristics?
a: Basal–bolus: most flexible but more injections/education
b: Premix: most flexible with minimal meal planning
d: GLP-1 RA: universally causes hypoglycemia alone
explanation: MDI is flexible; premix needs consistent meals; GLP-1 RA has low hypo risk alone. (Slides p. 9, 13–14)

the qustion: Which statement about premixed insulin is TRUE?
a: Ideal when meals are erratic and unpredictable
b: Fewer injections but less flexibility; meals should be consistent
explanation: Premix trades flexibility for convenience and routine. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: Which adverse effect cluster is MOST typical when starting GLP-1 RA therapy?
a: Nausea and early GI intolerance that improves with slow titration
explanation: GI effects early; low intrinsic hypoglycemia risk. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Adding which therapy to basal insulin often results in less weight gain and hypoglycemia than moving straight to basal–bolus insulin?
explanation: Basal + GLP-1 RA is an effective intensification option. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which patient scenario favors starting insulin now rather than GLP-1 RA first?
a: A1C just above target with no symptoms
b: Marked hyperglycemia with catabolic symptoms or ketonuria
c: Well-controlled fasting with mild post-lunch spikes
d: Preference to try once-weekly noninsulin injectable
explanation: Insulin promptly when very uncontrolled/symptomatic. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which of the following is an appropriate first mealtime insulin intensification step in a patient on basal insulin?
a: Add a small dose to the largest meal (‘basal-plus’)
c: Use prandial insulin only at bedtime
explanation: Add to largest meal; escalate stepwise as needed. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: A patient starting tirzepatide is concerned about hypoglycemia while not using insulin or SU. Best response?
a: High risk of hypoglycemia is expected
b: Low intrinsic hypoglycemia risk without insulin/SU, but monitor
explanation: Dual incretin therapy has low hypo risk alone. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which principle of basal insulin titration is emphasized?
a: Increase based on a single fasting value
b: Adjust using several days of fasting glucose patterns
d: Never change dose without lab A1C
explanation: Patterns, not isolated values, guide safe titration. (Slide p. 6)

the qustion: Which education point should be covered when starting insulin?
c: Do not rotate sites to avoid bruising
d: Room temperature extremes don’t affect insulin
explanation: Safety and technique training are essential. (Slides p. 15–17)

the qustion: Which statement about GLP-1 RA and weight is correct?
a: Associated with weight loss or neutrality
c: Weight is unchanged with any dose
explanation: Weight benefit is a core reason to prefer GLP-1 RA in many. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: A patient’s fasting values are controlled, but post-dinner readings are high and A1C is above goal. Which step fits best?
b: Add a small prandial insulin dose before dinner
explanation: Target the meal producing the largest excursion. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which regimen typically requires the most structured patient education but offers greatest meal flexibility?
explanation: MDI offers flexibility at the cost of complexity. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which is a reasonable reason to reduce basal insulin slightly when adding GLP-1 RA?
b: To prevent hypoglycemia if fasting is already near goal
d: Because GLP-1 RA works only on fasting values
explanation: Combination can lower glucose; adjust to avoid hypos. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which statement about injection sites is correct?
a: Rotate within and between sites to avoid lipohypertrophy
b: Always use the exact same spot
d: Site rotation does not affect absorption
explanation: Rotation prevents tissue changes and erratic absorption. (Slide p. 16)

the qustion: Which best distinguishes premix vs basal–bolus?
a: Premix: fewer injections; less flexible meals
b: Premix: more injections; more flexible meals
c: Basal–bolus: fewer injections and fixed meals
explanation: Premix simplifies injections but needs predictable meals. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: A patient with obesity, ASCVD risk factors, and suboptimal control on oral agents asks about injectables. Which option aligns with weight/CV considerations?
explanation: GLP-1 RAs can aid weight and some have CV benefit. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which is TRUE about GLP-1 RA GI effects?
a: Often transient and dose-related; slow titration helps
d: Improve by stopping rotation of sites
explanation: Start low, go slow; diet counsel helps. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which scenario BEST calls for insulin now?
b: Very high glucose with dehydration and ketonuria
explanation: Prompt insulin in symptomatic, marked hyperglycemia. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which statement about SMBG with insulin use is correct?
explanation: Glucose patterns drive dose changes and safety. (Slide p. 6)

the qustion: Education for hypoglycemia should include all EXCEPT:
d: When to adjust doses or seek help
explanation: Recurrent hypos need addressing, not ignoring. (Slide p. 15)

the qustion: Which is MOST consistent with the role of basal insulin?
a: Blunting fasting hepatic glucose output overnight
explanation: Basal suppresses hepatic output; prandial covers meals. (Slide p. 6)

the qustion: Which regimen is LEAST flexible for variable shift-work meals?
explanation: Premix needs fixed meal timing. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: Which statement about storage is TRUE?
a: Avoid extreme heat/cold; follow device-specific storage advice
explanation: Temperature and handling affect potency. (Slide p. 17)

the qustion: Which next step is reasonable when fasting is near goal but post-meal spikes persist on basal insulin?
a: Add GLP-1 RA or small prandial dose at the largest meal
c: Stop basal and start premix once weekly
explanation: Target postprandial hyperglycemia specifically. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which is TRUE regarding dual incretin therapy (e.g., tirzepatide)?
b: Low intrinsic hypoglycemia risk without insulin/SU
explanation: GLP-1/GIP agonism lowers glucose with weight benefit. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which counseling point for premix is MOST accurate?
b: Mealtime regularity and carbohydrate consistency are important
d: Premix eliminates the need for education
explanation: Consistent meals reduce hypo/variability risk. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: Which is an appropriate reason to choose basal–bolus over premix?
a: Need for maximal meal timing flexibility
b: Desire for the fewest possible injections
c: Strong preference to avoid carb counting
explanation: MDI favors flexibility but needs more engagement. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: When first adding a mealtime insulin in basal-plus, which meal is generally targeted?
a: The meal with the highest postprandial excursion
explanation: Start where the biggest spike occurs. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which of the following best describes clinical inertia?
a: Timely intensification when goals are missed
b: Delays in adjusting therapy despite not meeting targets
explanation: Avoid delaying intensification; reassess regularly. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Which is MOST consistent with patient selection for GLP-1 RA first?
a: Obesity, low hypo tolerance, desire to avoid insulin if possible
explanation: Weight/hypo profile favors GLP-1 RA unless insulin is urgently indicated. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which statement about insulin pens is correct?
a: They may improve dosing accuracy and convenience for many patients
b: They are less accurate than syringes in all cases
c: They eliminate the need for injection technique
d: They are not suitable for older adults
explanation: Pens can support accuracy and adherence. (Slide p. 16)

the qustion: Which education item belongs in sick-day guidance for insulin users?
a: Monitor more frequently and never stop basal insulin; seek help with ketones
explanation: Illness raises glucose/ketones—monitor and continue basal. (Slide p. 18)

the qustion: Which is TRUE regarding hypoglycemia education at initiation?
a: Discuss symptoms, precipitants, rapid treatment, and dose adjustments
b: Avoid discussing hypos to reduce anxiety
c: Teach to withhold carbs after hypos
explanation: Comprehensive safety counseling is essential. (Slide p. 15)

the qustion: A patient on basal insulin with good fasting results prefers fewer injections but struggles with lunch and dinner spikes. Which regimen fits their preference?
a: Premixed insulin twice daily with meal planning
explanation: Premix cuts injections but requires regular meals. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: Which best summarizes the role of GLP-1 RA vs insulin intensification?
a: GLP-1 RA often prior to prandial insulin due to weight and hypo benefits
b: GLP-1 RA always after full basal–bolus failure
c: GLP-1 RA reserved for T1D only
explanation: Class positioning emphasizes benefits before prandial insulin in many. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which is the BEST teaching point before first insulin injection?
a: Demonstrate pen priming, angle, depth, and site rotation
b: Instruct to skip rotation for consistency
d: Use boiling water to clean needles
explanation: Proper technique reduces complications and variability. (Slide p. 16)

the qustion: Which factor would push you toward insulin sooner rather than later?
explanation: Urgent control needed in symptomatic or ketotic patients. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which combination best pairs regimen with an expected trade-off?
a: Basal–bolus: more flexibility but more injections/education
b: Premix: more flexibility with fewer injections
c: Basal-only: covers all postprandial spikes reliably
d: GLP-1 RA: high hypoglycemia risk alone
explanation: Know trade-offs to tailor therapy. (Slides p. 9, 13–14)

the qustion: Which patient is LEAST suited for premixed insulin?
c: Need to reduce number of daily injections
explanation: Premix fits regular, predictable meals. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: Which statement about GLP-1 RA is TRUE?
a: Low intrinsic hypoglycemia risk when not combined with insulin/SU
d: Cannot be combined with basal insulin
explanation: Safety and combinations covered in slides. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which practical step helps mitigate early GLP-1 RA nausea?
c: Gradual up-titration with meal size guidance
explanation: Start low, go slow; dietary tips provided. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which of the following is the BEST rationale to choose basal + GLP-1 RA instead of moving straight to basal–bolus?
a: Desire to minimize hypoglycemia and weight gain
explanation: Basal + GLP-1 RA often achieves goals with fewer side effects. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which choice best reflects a stepwise insulin intensification pathway?
a: Basal → basal-plus (one meal) → basal–bolus as needed
b: Basal → stop insulin → oral agents only
d: Basal → random prandial doses without data
explanation: Structured progression is recommended. (Slide p. 13)
